newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Petron tenders to buy gasoline after two years.
newsitem.headline: Petron tenders to buy gasoline after two years.

text.p: Philippines oil refiner Petron Corp has issued its first spot tender in about two years to import unleaded gasoline for delivery in August, a company official said on Wednesday.
The tender seeks 70,000 barrels of 95-octane unleaded gasoline for August 11-15 delivery, on a cost-and-freight basis to Bataan.
The tender closes on July 18 and is vaild for the day.
"The last time we issued a tender to buy gasoline was in 1995," the official said.
The official said the tender was issued due to increased domestic demand.
But industry sources said the import requirement was also partly due to the unexpected shutdown of a 15,000-barrel-per-day (bpd) thermal cracker on June 20 following an explosion.
The unit, which produces diesel, gasoline and liquefied petroleum gas, is expected to be shut for about one month.
Petron, which is 40-percent owned by Saudi Aramco, operates a 155,000-bpd refinery in Bataan, north of the capital Manila.
The official said Petron went ahead with the decision to issue the import tender despite the de facto devaluation of the peso last week.

The peso has lost about 11.74 percent of its value after the central bank's announcement last Friday that it would allow the peso to trade in a wider band against the U.S. dollar. The peso was last trading at 28.90/29.00 to the dollar.
"We cannot postpone our purchase. There is a need for the product," the official said.
The official said Petron went ahead with the purchase as it was unclear if the substantial weakening of the peso would be temporary or permanent.
But the company is evaluating the need to raise domestic petrol prices following the devaluation, the official said.
Petron, the country's biggest refiner, reduced the price of unleaded premium gasoline by 20 centavos to 9.9365 pesos per litre on July 2 in reaction to lower Singapore posted prices.
